text: I'm Kim Severson with the New York Times
here in Savannah Georgia taking a deeper
look into Paula Deen's Empire
I spoke with Dora Charles a black cook
who for 20 years helped Paula run her
kitchens they were so close
Paula called Dora her soul sister but
now Dora Charles is telling a very
different story about life with Paula
Deen so did you two get along right away
were you fast friends we had all real
good she calling us sisters she is in
charge of that kitchen at the lady
incentive it's a southern dish you
better not put it out so you were
working seven days a week with her done
six days six days a week with them and
so she started the first lady in Sun at
3:11 Congress you know and you were her
main cook in there right did she talk to
you about your partnership about whether
you'd come along with her as she got
famous yes mm-hmm
she said think with me one day if I get
rich you get rich but since I get it
just passed you by it's just it's just
passing a guy you know I'm not gonna run
behind and say you promise me you
promise me where my half where my part
you know it wasn't no wasn't all about
that actually all I was looking for was
a good salary how much money were you
making when she started her Food Network
show I was just making six fifty six
dollars and fifty cents an hour in a
statement to the times Mrs Dean's
publicity team dismissed her claims her
grievances they said are about money not
race the statement describes her as
quote an employee that despite over 20
years of generosity feels that she still
deserves yet even more financial support
from Paula Deen I told her at times I
didn't have enough money to buy my own
medication we was sitting across the
table on table
and she said it didn't reach me and she
said here's $100 but buy your medicine
all the stories that we've heard about
her wanting of plantation wedding that
had black men dressed in suits concerns
about how she treated black employees
whether or not she used racial slurs you
feel all this is true yeah she wanted
general and not addressing like that as
well at the wedding
mm-hmm do you feel like Paula Deen is
racist in that way I do I do have you
ever heard Paula Deen use the n-word I
only use the word she say I tell y'all
y'all y'all that's what's wrong
with y'all down today why are
you coming forward now to tell your
story
because they didn't give me what I
deserve they didn't give me nothing I
deserve everything I got I work for it
even my own co-workers think that I've
been treated the best they think I live
in a mansion and it's just time that
everybody knows that Paula Deen don't
treat me the way they think she treat me
at the time of this interview mrs.
Charles was still working for mrs. Dean
at the lady and sons though the two
don't speak anymore she hasn't made
other employment plans but holds on to
her dream of one day opening her own
restaurant
you
